bdf_reader/
tokens.rs

1use paste::paste;
2use std::str::FromStr;
3use thiserror::Error;
4
5#[derive(Debug, Error)]
6#[error("No such variant: {0}")]
7pub struct NoSuchVariant(String);
8
9#[derive(Clone, Copy, Debug, Eq, PartialEq)]
10pub enum WritingDirection {
11	Horizontal = 0,
12	Vertical = 1,
13	Both = 2
14}
15
16impl FromStr for WritingDirection {
17	type Err = NoSuchVariant;
18
19	fn from_str(s: &str) -> Result<Self, Self::Err> {
20		match s {
21			"0" => Ok(Self::Horizontal),
22			"1" => Ok(Self::Vertical),
23			"2" => Ok(Self::Both),
24			_ => Err(NoSuchVariant(s.into()))
25		}
26	}
27}
28
29macro_rules! tokens {
30	(
31		$(#[doc$($doc:tt)*])*
32		$vis:vis enum $ident:ident {
33			$(
34				$(#[doc$($variant_doc:tt)*])*
35				$(#[test($test_input:literal, $test_expected:expr)])*
36				$variant:ident {
37					$tag:literal $(,
38						$($arg:ident: $arg_ty:ident),* $(,)?
39						$(..$remaining:ident)?
40					)?
41				}
42			),*
43		}
44	) => {
45		paste! {
46			$(#[doc$($doc)*])*
47			#[allow(clippy::derive_partial_eq_without_eq)]
48			#[derive(Clone, Debug, PartialEq)]
49			$vis enum $ident {
50				$(
51					$(#[doc$($variant_doc)*])*
52					$variant $({ $($arg: $arg_ty,)* $($remaining: String)? })?
53				),*
54			}
55
56			#[derive(Debug, Error)]
57			pub enum Error {
58				$(
59					$(
60						$(
61							#[error(
62								"Failed to parse argument {} of tag {}: {0}",
63								stringify!($arg),
64								$tag
65							)]
66							[<$variant $arg:camel>](#[source] <$arg_ty as FromStr>::Err),
67						)*
68					)?
69				)*
70
71				#[error("Missing the argument {1} of tag {0}")]
72				MissingArg(&'static str, &'static str),
73
74				#[error("Extra tokens after tag {0}")]
75				ExtraTokens(&'static str),
76
77				#[error("Unknown tag: {0}")]
78				UnknownTag(String)
79			}
80
81			impl $ident {
82				#[allow(unused_assignments, unused_mut)]
83				$vis fn parse_line(line: &str) -> Result<Self, Error> {
84					let mut tokens = line
85						.trim_end()
86						.split(|ch: char| ch.is_ascii_whitespace())
87						.peekable();
88
89					$(
90						if tokens.peek() == Some(&$tag) {
91							tokens.next().unwrap();
92							let mut empty = tokens.peek().is_none();
93							$(
94								$(
95									let $arg: $arg_ty = tokens
96										.next()
97										.ok_or(Error::MissingArg($tag, stringify!($arg)))?
98										.parse()
99										.map_err(Error::[<$variant $arg:camel>])?;
100									empty = tokens.peek().is_none();
101								)*
102								$(
103									let $remaining = tokens
104										.fold(String::new(), |mut rem, token| {
105											if !rem.is_empty() {
106												rem += " ";
107											}
108											rem += token;
109											rem
110										});
111									empty = true;
112								)?
113							)?
114							if !empty {
115								return Err(Error::ExtraTokens($tag));
116							}
117							return Ok(Self::$variant $({ $($arg,)* $($remaining)? })?);
118						}
119					)*
120
121					return Err(Error::UnknownTag(tokens.next().unwrap().into()));
122				}
123			}
124
125			$(
126				#[cfg(test)]
127				#[test]
128				fn [<test_ $ident:lower _parse_ $variant:lower>]() {
129					$(
130						let expected: $ident = {
131							use $ident::*;
132							$test_expected
133						};
134						assert_eq!(expected, $ident::parse_line($test_input).unwrap());
135					)*
136				}
137			)*
138		}
139	};
140}
141
142// https://adobe-type-tools.github.io/font-tech-notes/pdfs/5005.BDF_Spec.pdf
143tokens! {
144	pub enum Token {
145		/// `STARTFONT` is followed by a version number indicating the exact file format
146		/// used (for example, 2.1).
147		#[test("STARTFONT 2.1", StartFont { ver: "2.1".into() })]
148		StartFont { "STARTFONT", ver: String },
149
150		/// One or more lines beginning with the word `COMMENT`. These lines can be
151		/// ignored by any program reading the file.
152		#[test("COMMENT hello world", Comment { comment: "hello world".into() })]
153		Comment { "COMMENT", ..comment },
154
155		/// (Optional) The value of `CONTENTVERSION` is an integer which can be
156		/// assigned by an installer program to keep track of the version of the included
157		/// data. The value is intended to be valid only in a single environment, under
158		/// the control of a single installer. The value of `CONTENTVERSION` should only
159		/// reflect upgrades to the quality of the bitmap images, not to the glyph
160		/// complement or encoding.
161		#[test("CONTENTVERSION 1", ContentVersion { ver: 1 })]
162		ContentVersion { "CONTENTVERSION", ver: i32 },
163
164		/// `FONT` is followed by the font name, which should exactly match the
165		/// Post-Script™ language **FontName** in the corresponding outline font program
166		#[test("FONT font-name", Font { name: "font-name".into() })]
167		Font { "FONT", name: String },
168
169		/// `SIZE` is followed by the point size of the glyphs and the x and y resolutions
170		/// of the device for which the font is intended.
171		#[test("SIZE 16 75 75", Size { pt: 16, xres: 75, yres: 75 })]
172		Size { "SIZE", pt: u32, xres: u32, yres: u32 },
173
174		/// `FONTBOUNDINGBOX` is followed by the width in x and the height in y, and
175		/// the x and y displacement of the lower left corner from origin 0 (for
176		/// horizontal writing direction); all in integer pixel values.
177		#[test(
178			"FONTBOUNDINGBOX 16 16 0 -2",
179			FontBoundingBox { fbbx: 16, fbby: 16, xoff: 0, yoff: -2 }
180		)]
181		FontBoundingBox { "FONTBOUNDINGBOX", fbbx: u32, fbby: u32, xoff: i32, yoff: i32 },
182
183		/// (Optional) The integer value of `METRICSSET  may be 0, 1, or 2, which
184		/// scorrepond to writing direction 0 only, 1 only, or both (respectively). If not
185		/// present, `METRICSSET` 0 is implied. If `METRICSSET` is 1, `DWIDTH` and
186		/// `SWIDTH` keywords are optional.
187		#[test("METRICSSET 0", MetricsSet { dir: WritingDirection::Horizontal })]
188		#[test("METRICSSET 1", MetricsSet { dir: WritingDirection::Vertical })]
189		#[test("METRICSSET 2", MetricsSet { dir: WritingDirection::Both })]
190		MetricsSet { "METRICSSET", dir: WritingDirection },
191
192		/// `SWIDTH` is followed by swx0 and swy0, the scalable width of the glyph in x
193		/// and y for writing mode 0. The scalable widths are of type Number and are in
194		/// units of 1/1000th of the size of the glyph and correspond to the widths found
195		/// in AFM files (for outline fonts). If the size of the glyph is p points, the
196		/// width information must be scaled by p/1000 to get the width of the glyph in
197		/// printer’s points. This width information should be regarded as a vector
198		/// indicating the position of the next glyph’s origin relative to the origin of
199		/// this glyph. `SWIDTH` is mandatory for all writing mode 0 fonts.
200		///
201		/// To convert the scalable width to the width in device pixels, multiply `SWIDTH`
202		/// times p/1000 times r/72, where r is the device resolution in pixels per inch.
203		/// The result is a real number giving the ideal width in device pixels. The
204		/// actual device width must be an integral number of device pixels and is given
205		/// by the `DWIDTH` entry.
206		#[test("SWIDTH 1000 0", SWidth { swx0: 1000.0, swy0: 0.0 })]
207		SWidth { "SWIDTH", swx0: f64, swy0: f64 },
208
209		/// `DWIDTH` specifies the widths in x and y, dwx0 and dwy0, in device pixels.
210		/// Like `SWIDTH`, this width information is a vector indicating the position of
211		/// the next glyph’s origin relative to the origin of this glyph. `DWIDTH` is
212		/// mandatory for all writing mode 0 fonts.
213		#[test("DWIDTH 16 0", DWidth { dwx0: 16.0, dwy0: 0.0 })]
214		DWidth { "DWIDTH", dwx0: f64, dwy0: f64 },
215
216		/// `SWIDTH1` is followed by the values for swx1 and swy1, the scalable width of
217		/// the glyph in x and y, for writing mode 1 (vertical direction). The values are
218		/// of type Number, and represent the widths in glyph space coordinates.
219		#[test("SWIDTH1 1000 0", SWidthVertical { swx1: 1000.0, swy1: 0.0 })]
220		SWidthVertical { "SWIDTH1", swx1: f64, swy1: f64 },
221
222		/// `DWIDTH1` specifies the integer pixel width of the glyph in x and y. Like
223		/// `SWIDTH1`, this width information is a vector indicating the position of the
224		/// next glyph’s origin relative to the origin of this glyph. `DWIDTH1` is
225		/// mandatory for all writing mode 1 fonts.
226		#[test("DWIDTH1 16 0", DWidthVertical { dwx1: 16.0, dwy1: 0.0 })]
227		DWidthVertical { "DWIDTH1", dwx1: f64, dwy1: f64 },
228
229		/// `VVECTOR` (optional) specifies the components of a vector from origin 0 (the
230		/// origin for writing direction 0) to origin 1 (the origin for writing direction
231		/// 1). If the value of `METRICSSET` is 1 or 2, `VVECTOR` must be specified either
232		/// at the global level, or for each individual glyph. If specified at the global
233		/// level, the `VVECTOR` is the same for all glyphs, though the inclusion of this
234		/// keyword in an individual glyph has the effect of overriding the bal value for
235		/// that specific glyph.
236		#[test("VVECTOR 1 1", VVector { xoff: 1.0, yoff: 1.0 })]
237		VVector { "VVECTOR", xoff: f64, yoff: f64 },
238
239		/// The optional word `STARTPROPERTIES` may be followed by the number of
240		/// properties (n) that follow. Within the properties list, there may be n lines
241		/// consisting of a word for the property name followed by either an integer or
242		/// string surrounded by ASCII double quotation marks (ASCII octal 042).
243		/// Internal quotation characters are indicated (or “quoted”) by using two
244		/// quotation characters in a row.
245		#[test("STARTPROPERTIES 1", StartProperties { n: 1 })]
246		StartProperties { "STARTPROPERTIES", n: usize },
247
248		/// The word `ENDPROPERTIES` is used to delimit the end of the optional properties
249		/// list in fonts files containing the word `STARTPROPERTIES`.
250		#[test("ENDPROPERTIES", EndProperties {})]
251		EndProperties { "ENDPROPERTIES" },
252
253		/// `CHARS` is followed by *nglyphs*, the number of glyphs that follow. To make
254		/// sure that the correct number of glyphs were actually read and processed, error
255		/// checking is recommended at the end of the file
256		#[test("CHARS 1", Chars { nglyphs: 1 })]
257		Chars { "CHARS", nglyphs: usize },
258
259		/// The word `STARTCHAR` followed by a string containing the name for the
260		/// glyph. In base fonts, this should correspond to the name in the PostScript
261		/// language outline font’s encoding vector. In a Composite font (Type 0), the
262		/// value may be a numeric offset or glyph ID.
263		#[test("STARTCHAR U+0041", StartChar { name: "U+0041".into() })]
264		StartChar { "STARTCHAR", name: String },
265
266		/// `ENCODING` is followed by a positive integer representing the Adobe Standard
267		/// Encoding value. If the character is not in the Adobe Standard Encoding,
268		/// `ENCODING` is followed by –1 and optionally by another integer specifying
269		/// the glyph index for the non-standard encoding.
270		// TODO represent the optional encoding value
271		#[test("ENCODING 65", Encoding { enc: 65 })]
272		Encoding { "ENCODING", enc: u32 },
273
274		/// `BBX` is followed by BBw, the width of the black pixels in x, and BBh, the
275		/// height in y. These are followed by the x and y displacement, BBxoff0 and
276		/// BByoff0, of the lower left corner of the bitmap from origin 0. All values are
277		/// are an integer number of pixels.
278		///
279		/// If the font specifies metrics for writing direction 1, `VVECTOR` specifies the
280		/// offset from origin 0 to origin 1. For example, for writing direction 1, the
281		/// offset from origin 1 to the lower left corner of the bitmap would be:
282		///
283		/// BBxoff1x,y = BBxoff0x,y – `VVECTOR`
284		#[test("BBX 16 16 0 -2", BoundingBox { bbw: 16, bbh: 16, bbxoff: 0, bbyoff: -2 })]
285		BoundingBox { "BBX", bbw: u32, bbh: u32, bbxoff: i32, bbyoff: i32 },
286
287		/// `BITMAP` introduces the hexadecimal data for the character bitmap. From the
288		/// `BBX` value for h, find h lines of hex-encoded bitmap, padded on the right
289		/// with zero’s to the nearest byte (that is, multiple of 8). Hex data can be
290		/// turned into binary by taking two bytes at a time, each of which represents 4
291		/// bits of the 8-bit value. For example, the byte 01101101 is two hex digits: 6
292		/// (0110 in hex) and D (1101 in hex).
293		#[test("BITMAP", Bitmap {})]
294		Bitmap { "BITMAP" },
295
296		/// `ENDCHAR` delimits the end of the glyph description
297		#[test("ENDCHAR", EndChar {})]
298		EndChar { "ENDCHAR" },
299
300		/// The entire file is terminated with the word `ENDFONT`. If this is encountered
301		/// before all of the glyphs have been read, it is an error cond
302		#[test("ENDFONT", EndFont {})]
303		EndFont { "ENDFONT" }
304	}
305}
